thread.title_full: You might have to wait 18 months for the Dow to make back what it lost - MarketWatch

author: Tomi Kilgore
title: You might have to wait 18 months for the Dow to make back what it lost
text:
FactSet It could take the Dow 385 weekdays to make back what it lost Why would anyone want to sell stocks, when they know the market will always rise to new highs again eventually? Maybe it’s because they don’t want to wait 18 months for the Dow Jones Industrial Average to get back what it lost.
There’s a tendency for investors and analysts to see a sharp, historic selloff in the Dow DJIA, -0.25% and believe that’s an all-clear signal to buy stocks. Like billionaire investment guru Warren Buffett says, be greedy when others are fearful. Read more about Buffett Quote: s .
Online investing platforms experienced a spike in new account creation and deposits earlier this week as the Dow tumbled into correction territory for the first time in years. Wall Street analysts also cheered the improved “valuation” and “risk-versus-reward” profiles, as 11 Dow stocks were upgraded over the last week, while just one was downgraded, based on data provided by FactSet.
After falling 1,897 points amid a six-session losing streak through Tuesday, the Dow bounced 988 points the past two sessions, the largest two-day point gain in history. On Friday, the Dow slipped 42 points in morning trade.
But before new investors pat themselves on the back for buying on the recent dip, they should keep in mind that Buffett also said, some things take time.
Bloomberg Can you afford to wait as long as Warren Buffett can to start making money? The Dow’s 52-week low this week came less than 70 weekdays after it reached a 52-week high, the ninth-fastest the index has done that in its history, according to data provided by Sundial Capital Research.
In all, there were 21 times the Dow went from a new high to a new low in less than 100 days, according to Sundial Research. The data show that after those declines, the median number of days it takes to get back to a new 52-week high is 5.5 times the number of days it took to hit a new low. That suggests the Dow might not make back what it lost for 385 days (77 weeks), or about a year and a half.
Another saying often heard on Wall Street, and attributed to famed economist John Maynard Keynes, is that the market can remain irrational longer than investors can remain solvent.
The bounce back after Black Monday in October 1987, when the Dow crashed 23% in one day, might have seemed very quick to rattled investors, but it still took 262 weekdays, or just over a year. And after the low hit in September 2001, it took about two years to make everything back.
Sundial President Jason Goepfert said the damage done by the recent tumble was “severe,” so it’s unlikely to see stocks shoot right back up to new highs like nothing happened.
“It will take time to work off the kind of selling we’ve seen,” Goepfert said.
